importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update indicates the most recent information on the Louvre theft, a critical event in cultural history and national security.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time period during which the jewelry was created and used by French royalty, particularly Napoleon and Empress Eugénie, contextualizes the historical and cultural significance of the stolen items.

keyTakeAways: Nine high-value artifacts were stolen from the Louvre Museum in Paris in a seven-minute heist targeting the Apollo Gallery, which houses the French Crown Jewels.
The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace and earrings gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces from Empress Eugénie’s personal collection.
The sapphire diadem features 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds and was previously owned by the Orléans family before being acquired by the Louvre in 1985.
The emerald necklace and earrings, given by Napoleon to Marie-Louise in 1810, were preserved and sold to the Louvre in 2004 for 3.7 million euros.
The reliquary brooch, made for Empress Eugénie in 1855, contains the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, historically significant as gifts from Cardinal Mazarin to Louis XIV.
A silver, gold, and diamond bow brooch from Eugénie’s 1855 belt was bought in 2008 by the Louvre for 6.72 million euros.
One of the items, Eugénie’s crown, was targeted by thieves but recovered outside the museum, though damaged.
Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the historical, cultural, and symbolic value of the pieces.
Thieves are believed to have dismantled the stolen jewelry, melting down gold and silver, which raises concerns about permanent loss of cultural heritage.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a major cultural heist on October 20, 2025, nine historically significant artifacts were stolen from the Louvre Museum in Paris in a seven-minute heist targeting the Apollo Gallery, which houses the French Crown Jewels. Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace and earrings gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces from Empress Eugénie’s collection, including a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch. The sapphire diadem, worn by queens including Hortense, Marie-Amélie, and Isabelle d’Orléans, contains 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds. The emerald necklace, crafted by François-Régnault Nitot, was gifted by Napoleon in 1810 and later acquired by the Louvre in 2004. The reliquary brooch, made for Empress Eugénie by Paul-Alfred Bapst in 1855 and containing the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, was also stolen. A silver-gold bow brooch, derived from a belt worn by Eugénie in 1855, was acquired by the Louvre in 2008. While the crown of Empress Eugénie was stolen and damaged, it was recovered outside the museum. Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' due to the irreplaceable historical and symbolic value of the items. Experts believe the thieves dismantled the jewelry, melting down gold and silver, which represents a permanent loss of cultural heritage. The theft raises global concerns about the security of priceless historical artifacts and the vulnerability of France’s cultural treasures.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
